title: Induced current - work done on moving loop

content.question: A <math alttext="3.0 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> wide and <math alttext="5.0 centimeters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>cm</mi></math> long rectangular loop of conducting wire of resistance <math alttext="0.2 ohm" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.2</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">Ω</mi></math>, is moved at a constant speed of <math alttext="3.0 meters per second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3.0</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mtext>m/s</mtext></math> to the right. The loop enters, passes through, and exits a <math alttext="0.5 tesla" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.5</mn><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></math> magnetic field directed out of the page, as shown. The loop is always moved at a constant speed. What is the work done by the magnetic field on the loop?

skill.text: 2.B: Calculate or estimate an unknown quantity with units from known quantities, by selecting and following a logical computational pathway.
